content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Abby Schweighardt: I was born in Chicago, but I grew up in a small town in the East North Central region, where I lived with my parents and two younger siblings. My father is a teacher with a bachelor's degree, and my mother is a nurse who went back to school for her graduate degree when I was in high school. We were never really poor, but we weren't rolling in money either. My parents always emphasized education and hard work, which is why I ended up going to college right after high school. I studied sociology and later got my master's in public policy, which led me to my current job in nonprofit work focused on education equity. I got married a few years ago to my college sweetheart, and we live in Evanston now. Life hasn't been without its challenges—my husband had a temporary illness a few months ago, which is why I'm not at work right now—but overall, I feel lucky and grateful for the path I'm on.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Abby Schweighardt: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads moment for me—right after I graduated from college. I had just finished my bachelor's in sociology and was trying to figure out what I wanted to do next. I had a few options: I could have gone into social work, which was something I had always been interested in, or I could have pursued a master's degree in public policy, which was a path my mother encouraged me to take because of her own experience in healthcare policy. I was torn because both paths felt meaningful, but I wasn't sure which one would give me the most impact. I remember sitting on my parents' porch one evening, staring at the lake, and thinking about what kind of life I wanted to build. I realized that if I wanted to work on systemic change, especially in education, a master's in public policy would give me the tools to do that more effectively. So I decided to go that route. That decision led me to my current work in nonprofit education equity, which is something I'm incredibly passionate about. Looking back, I don't think I would have made the same choice if I hadn't had the support of my family and the confidence to take a risk on my own path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Abby Schweighardt: I think for me, it was a conscious choice, but one that felt almost inevitable once I took the time to reflect. I wasn't just choosing between two careers—I was choosing the kind of person I wanted to be. I remember talking to my mother that night, and she said something that stuck with me: 'You don't have to follow me, Abby, but you should follow what lights you up.' That made me realize that I wasn't just making a decision for my future, but also honoring the values my parents instilled in me. I didn't just 'fall into' public policy; I chose it because I believed in its potential to create real change. And even now, when I feel uncertain, I go back to that moment on the porch, looking at the lake, and remind myself why I made that choice.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Abby Schweighardt: Absolutely, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate more as I've grown in my career. When I was deciding between social work and public policy, my mother was a huge support, but I also had a professor from my sociology classes who took me under her wing. She had worked in nonprofit education reform and saw potential in me. She invited me to a few meetings and introduced me to people in the field. That exposure was invaluable—it helped me see the practical side of policy work and how it could directly impact students and schools. Without her guidance, I might have stayed in the more traditional social work path. It's amazing how one person's belief in you can open doors you didn't even know existed. I try to pay that forward now by mentoring students who are considering similar paths, because I know how much it meant to me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Abby Schweighardt: Yes, I have a partner—my husband, Daniel. We met in college, actually, during our junior year. He was majoring in environmental science, and I was in sociology. We bonded over our shared passion for social justice and making the world a better place. We got married right after I finished my master's, and we've been together for almost six years now. We don't have any children yet, but we're both focused on building a stable foundation for our future. Daniel works as a sustainability consultant, so we're both pretty career-driven. He's been incredibly supportive of my work in education equity, and I admire how he balances his job with being a thoughtful and present partner. We live in Evanston now, and I love how close we are to the lake—it reminds me of that moment on my parents' porch when I made my big decision. Family has always been important to me, and I'm grateful to have someone who shares my values and helps me stay grounded.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my journey. It was interesting to revisit my childhood, my parents' influence, and the pivotal moment after college when I chose my path. I realized how much my family and mentors shaped my decisions, especially the choice to pursue public policy over social work. It's amazing how one conversation on my parents' porch, combined with the support of a professor, led me to where I am today. Talking about my husband and our shared values reminded me of how important it is to have a partner who supports your dreams. I'm grateful for the life I've built and the people who have helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Abby Schweighardt: My immediate family includes my parents, my two younger siblings, and my husband, Daniel. My parents are still very much a part of my life—they live just a few towns over in Naperville, and we try to visit them as much as possible. My younger sister, Sarah, is a high school teacher, and she's always been a source of inspiration for me. She's the one who encouraged me to get involved in education reform early on, even before I went to college. My other brother, Mark, is a software developer, and while our careers are very different, we have a lot of respect for each other's work. Our relationship is pretty close, even though we all have our own lives now. My parents are proud of what I've accomplished, and I think they're especially happy that I've found a career that aligns with my values. I also have a close relationship with my in-laws, who are very supportive of Daniel and me. They live in Madison, Wisconsin, and we visit them every summer. Family has always been a cornerstone of my life, and I'm grateful for the love and support I've always had.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Abby Schweighardt: Absolutely, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Priya, who I met during my first year of college. She was one of the first people to really challenge me intellectually and push me to think critically about the world. We became close during our sociology classes, and even though we went on different career paths—she ended up in urban planning—we still keep in touch and collaborate on projects related to community development. Another person who has had a big impact on my life is my college roommate, Emily. She's now a journalist, and she's always been the one to remind me of the importance of storytelling and how it can be a powerful tool for change. I also have a group of friends from my master's program who I stay in touch with; we meet up a few times a year for dinner or a weekend getaway. They've all been through similar career transitions, so it's comforting to have that support system. Friends like these have been a huge part of my journey, offering both encouragement and perspective when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Abby Schweighardt: I live in Evanston now, and it's a place that feels like home in a lot of ways. The neighborhood I'm in is a mix of historic homes and newer developments, with a strong sense of community. There are a lot of families here, which I really appreciate, and the local schools are some of the best in the state. I love walking along the lakefront—it's peaceful and reminds me of the place where I made that big decision about my career. The city has a vibrant cultural scene, with lots of art galleries, cafes, and community events. I also enjoy the fact that Evanston is pretty walkable, so I can easily get to work, the grocery store, or a coffee shop without needing a car. It's not perfect—like anywhere, there are challenges, especially around housing affordability—but overall, I feel like I've found a place that aligns with my values. It's also close to Chicago, which means I can take advantage of all the opportunities the city has to offer while still enjoying the slower pace of suburban life. I think that balance is really important to me, and I'm grateful to have found it here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Abby Schweighardt: I feel very safe in Evanston, which is something I didn't take for granted at first. When I moved here, I was a bit nervous about living in a bigger city, even though it's a suburb. But over time, I've come to appreciate the sense of community and the way people look out for each other here. I've never felt unsafe walking alone at night, even along the lakefront, which is something I used to worry about in more urban areas. The local police department is responsive, and there's a lot of neighborhood watch activity. Plus, the diversity of people here creates a natural sense of safety—there's a lot of mutual respect and shared values. I think it also helps that I've built a life here with people I care about, which makes the place feel even more secure. Overall, I feel like Evanston is a place where I can be myself and live without fear, which is something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Abby Schweighardt: Living here has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. One of the things I love about Evanston is the strong sense of community and the opportunities it offers, especially for someone in my field. There are so many nonprofits and advocacy groups focused on education and social justice, which makes it easy to get involved and feel like I'm making a difference. That said, the cost of living here is definitely a challenge. Even though I have a stable job, housing prices have gone up so much that I'm constantly thinking about whether we're making the right financial decisions for the long term. I also miss having more green space—while the lakefront is beautiful, I sometimes wish there were more parks and trails nearby for my husband and me to enjoy with friends. Still, I think the pros outweigh the cons. I feel like I'm in a place where I can grow both personally and professionally, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my environment shapes my daily life and sense of security. Talking about my husband, Daniel, and our shared values reminded me of how important it is to have a partner who supports your dreams and goals. It also made me appreciate how close we are to the lake, a place that holds so much meaning for me—both as a reminder of my past decisions and as a peaceful space in my present life. When I described Evanston, I realized how much I value the sense of community here, and how it makes me feel safe and connected. Even though there are challenges like the cost of living, I feel grateful for the opportunities and the people who make this place feel like home.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Abby Schweighardt: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. I usually start my week with a few early mornings—sometimes I'm up before my husband, Daniel, to get a few hours of work in before he leaves for his job as a sustainability consultant. On Mondays, I tend to focus on planning and meetings, especially since I work with a few different nonprofits and community organizations. Wednesdays are often my busiest day, with a mix of client meetings, policy research, and sometimes even community outreach events. Fridays are usually a bit more relaxed, and I try to make sure we have some time to unwind, whether it's a walk by the lake or a quiet dinner at home. On the weekends, we like to explore the area—sometimes we go to Chicago for concerts or museum exhibits, or we take a day trip to somewhere like Milwaukee or Madison. I also try to set aside time for self-care, like yoga or reading, because I think it's important to stay balanced. There are definitely days when I feel overwhelmed, especially with the demands of my job and the cost of living here, but I try to remind myself that I'm doing work I care about, and that gives me a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Abby Schweighardt: I work as a policy analyst for a nonprofit organization focused on education equity, and I also consult with a few local school districts on policy reform initiatives. My job is pretty flexible, which is both a blessing and a challenge. Most days, I'm in the office from around 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I often end up working late, especially when I'm preparing reports or attending meetings with stakeholders. I also have some remote work days, which helps me balance my responsibilities with my personal life. Because I'm not at work right now due to a temporary illness my husband is dealing with, I've had more time to reflect on my career path and how far I've come. It's interesting to think about how my early experiences—like that conversation on my parents' porch—shaped the kind of work I do now. I feel fortunate to be in a field where I can make a tangible difference, even if the days are long and the work is demanding.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Abby Schweighardt: In addition to my work, I have a few other routines that help me stay grounded. Every morning, I try to have a quiet cup of coffee on the porch, just like my parents did when I was growing up. It's a small ritual, but it helps me start the day with intention. I also make it a point to cook most evenings—Daniel and I have a rotating list of meals we try to make each week, and it's a nice way to connect. I've always had a passion for baking, so I often make bread or cookies on the weekends, sometimes to share with friends or neighbors. I also volunteer a few hours a month with a local literacy program, which ties back to my work in education equity. It's a way to give back in a more direct, personal way. And, of course, I make time for my faith—attending Mass on Sundays and reflecting on my values is something that's always been important to me. These routines, big and small, help me feel balanced and connected to the life I've built.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Abby Schweighardt: One of the most recent changes to my daily routine has been adjusting to having more time at home while Daniel is on temporary leave due to his illness. It's been a bit of a shift for both of us—normally, we're both pretty busy with work, so having this extra time together has been both a blessing and a challenge. I've found myself taking on more household responsibilities, which I didn't used to do as much, and it's been a good reminder of how much I value the little things, like cooking together or just sitting on the porch in the evenings. I've also started using this time to catch up on reading, especially books related to education policy and social justice, which has been both relaxing and intellectually stimulating. It's funny how life can change in unexpected ways, and while I miss the routine of work, I'm also grateful for the chance to slow down and reconnect with my husband and our shared values.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Abby Schweighardt: Actually, we don't have any children yet, but we're both really focused on building a stable foundation for our future together. We've talked a lot about starting a family, but we want to make sure we're in a good place financially and emotionally before taking that next step. Right now, we're both pretty career-driven, and we're enjoying the time we have to grow our professional lives and deepen our relationship. I think when we're ready, we'll take it one step at a time, just like we've done with everything else in our lives. For now, we're content with our routine, our work, and the life we've built together in Evanston.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my environment, relationships, and daily routines shape who I am and how I live. Talking about my family, especially Daniel, reminded me of how important it is to have a partner who not only supports your dreams but also shares your values and helps you stay grounded. It also made me appreciate how much the lakefront and the sense of community in Evanston contribute to my sense of safety and belonging. Describing my work and daily routines brought back memories of that pivotal moment on my parents' porch, where I made the decision to pursue public policy. It's amazing how that choice, along with the support of my family and mentors, has led me to where I am today. Even though there are challenges, like the cost of living and the demands of my job, I feel grateful for the life I've built and the people who make it meaningful.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Abby Schweighardt: In terms of my health, I've been pretty fortunate overall. I try to maintain a balanced lifestyle with regular exercise, a healthy diet, and mindfulness practices like yoga and meditation. I've always been active, partly because of growing up near the lake and having a love for walking and swimming. That said, I've had my share of challenges—my husband's recent illness has been a significant stressor, and while I'm not dealing with any chronic conditions myself, I've definitely felt the toll of stress and burnout over the years, especially with the demands of my job. I've learned to prioritize self-care more than I used to, and I've started seeing a therapist periodically to help manage the pressures of work and life. I also take my faith seriously, and attending Mass on Sundays gives me a sense of peace and grounding. I think it's important to be honest about the fact that no one is immune to health struggles, but I've been lucky to have a strong support system and a mindset that values both physical and mental well-being.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Abby Schweighardt: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, living near the lake gives me so many opportunities to stay active—whether it's a morning walk, a swim, or just sitting on the porch and breathing in the fresh air. I also find that having a routine, like my morning coffee on the porch or my weekly yoga sessions, helps me stay grounded and physically active. But the hardest part is balancing that with the demands of my job. There are days when I'm so caught up in meetings, reports, and policy work that I forget to take breaks or prioritize rest. I've learned that I need to be intentional about it—setting reminders to stretch, drink water, or take a short walk during the day. I also struggle with stress, especially when I'm juggling work and family responsibilities, but I've started to lean more on my support system—my husband, my friends, and even my faith—to help me stay mentally and emotionally healthy. It's not always easy, but I've come to see health as something I have to nurture, not just maintain.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Abby Schweighardt: In the past two years, the biggest health-related event for me was when Daniel was diagnosed with a temporary illness that required him to take a few months off work. It was a stressful time for both of us, not just because of the uncertainty of his health, but also because it forced me to step into more responsibilities at home and adjust my own work schedule. While I didn't have any major medical diagnoses myself, the stress of caring for him and managing my job took a toll on my mental health. I remember feeling overwhelmed at times, especially when I was juggling meetings, policy work, and household duties. It was during that time that I started seeing a therapist regularly, which was a huge turning point for me. I learned how to set boundaries, practice self-compassion, and prioritize my own well-being. It wasn't easy, but it taught me the importance of asking for help and taking care of myself, even when life feels chaotic. I'm grateful that Daniel is recovering now, and I've come out of this experience with a deeper understanding of how interconnected our health is—both physically and emotionally.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Abby Schweighardt: It's true, health challenges can disrupt so much of life, and in my case, Daniel's illness did affect how I balanced work and home. For a while, I was stretched thin, trying to manage my job, take care of him, and keep our household running smoothly. There were days when I felt like I wasn't doing enough for either of us, and that took a toll on my mental health. But what I learned through that experience was how important it is to lean on others—whether it's family, friends, or even professional support like therapy. I also realized that my ability to work through that period was tied to the resilience I've built over the years, both from my career and my faith. It reminded me that even when life throws curveballs, having a strong support system and a mindset that prioritizes well-being can make all the difference. I'm still navigating the aftermath of that time, but I feel stronger for having gone through it, and I'm more aware than ever of how deeply connected our health is to every other part of our lives.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Abby Schweighardt: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also a lot of challenges. On one hand, I feel more grounded than ever in my work and my relationships. I've really come to appreciate the balance we've found in Evanston, and I've made some meaningful connections with colleagues and community members who share my passion for education equity. I've also grown a lot personally, especially through the experience of supporting Daniel during his illness. That time forced me to slow down and really reflect on what matters most in life. I've become more intentional about my time, my health, and the people I surround myself with. On the other hand, there's been a lot of stress, especially with the ongoing cost of living here and the pressure of trying to make an impact in my field. I sometimes feel like I'm fighting against the system, but I remind myself that change takes time, and I'm doing the work that aligns with my values. Overall, I feel like I'm in a good place—more resilient, more connected, and more aware of the importance of showing up for myself and the people I love.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily life and health are intertwined with the people and routines I've built over the years. Talking about the changes in my routine while Daniel was on leave reminded me of how adaptable I can be, even in the face of unexpected challenges. It also made me realize how important it is to take time for myself, whether it's through reading, yoga, or just sitting on the porch with a cup of coffee. Describing my health and the challenges I've faced—especially during Daniel's illness—helped me process how deeply connected our well-being is to the support systems we create. I've come to see health not just as something to maintain, but as something to nurture, and I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Abby Schweighardt: I think I've definitely struggled with anxiety at times, especially during periods of high stress or uncertainty. When Daniel was unwell, I found myself constantly worrying about his health, our financial stability, and whether I was doing enough to support him. There were moments when I felt overwhelmed and questioned my ability to handle everything. I didn't necessarily have a formal diagnosis, but I know what anxiety feels like—those racing thoughts, the difficulty sleeping, and the sense that everything is on your shoulders. What helped me was opening up to a therapist and learning coping strategies like mindfulness and journaling. I also found comfort in my faith and in the support of my friends and family. I've come to see anxiety not as something to be ashamed of, but as a sign that I need to slow down, take a breath, and remind myself that I'm not alone. I'm still learning how to manage it, but I'm grateful for the tools I've gained and the understanding that mental health is just as important as physical health.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Abby Schweighardt: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and growth. Daniel's illness was tough on all of us, but it also brought us closer together. My parents have been incredibly supportive, coming up to visit as much as they can and helping out whenever they can. My siblings have been there too—Sarah, my sister, even helped me find some resources for mental health support, and Mark has been a steady presence, always checking in and offering advice. It's been hard watching Daniel go through this, but it's also made me realize how important it is to have a family that lifts each other up. I think we've all grown through this experience, and I'm grateful for the strength we've found in each other.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Abby Schweighardt: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life. Being Catholic, I grew up attending Mass every Sunday, and even now, it's a practice I hold dear. It's not just about the rituals or the traditions—it's about the sense of community, the comfort of knowing I'm part of something larger than myself, and the values that guide me through both good times and difficult ones. My faith has been especially important during challenging moments, like when Daniel was unwell. It gave me a sense of peace and reminded me that I'm not alone in facing life's struggles. I also find solace in prayer and reflection, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed by work or personal responsibilities. While I don't always have all the answers, I believe that faith helps me stay grounded and connected to the people and purpose that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Abby Schweighardt: I do use social media, though not as much as I used to. I have a Facebook account where I stay in touch with family and old friends, especially my parents and siblings. I also follow a few pages related to education policy and social justice, which help me stay informed about the issues I care about. Instagram is more for personal inspiration—sometimes I follow accounts that share beautiful nature photos or mindfulness tips, which help me take a step back from the busier parts of my life. I'm not really into Twitter, to be honest; I find it too fast-paced and often overwhelming. I do use LinkedIn professionally, mostly to network with other people in my field and stay updated on policy discussions. Social media isn't everything for me, but I do think it has its place in keeping me connected to both my personal and professional communities. I try to be intentional about how I use it, though—I don't want it to take over my time or add more stress to my life.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Abby Schweighardt: I think social media has played a smaller role for me during tough times, but it's still been helpful in certain ways. When Daniel was unwell, I didn't turn to Facebook or Twitter for emotional support as much as I did to my close friends and family. That said, I did find comfort in some online communities focused on mental health and caregiving—there were a few Facebook groups where people shared resources, tips, and just general encouragement, which was really valuable. I also used LinkedIn to connect with other professionals who had gone through similar challenges, which helped me feel less isolated in my work. Financial support wasn't something I sought through social media, but I did follow a few advocacy groups that raised funds for healthcare access, which aligned with my values. Overall, I think social media is a tool, and it's important to use it mindfully. For me, it's more about staying connected to the people and causes that matter, rather than relying on it as a primary source of support.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how health challenges, both my own and those of the people I love, shape our lives in ways we often don't anticipate. Talking about Daniel's illness and how it affected my mental health reminded me of the strength I found in vulnerability—both in asking for help and in allowing myself to feel overwhelmed. It also made me realize how interconnected our well-being is; when one person is struggling, it ripples through the entire family and community. Describing my anxiety and the tools I've learned to manage it helped me see how important it is to prioritize mental health, not just as a personal responsibility but as a collective one. I'm grateful for the support I've received and for the lessons I've learned about resilience, self-compassion, and the power of connection during difficult times.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Abby Schweighardt: In the past year, my level of stress has definitely fluctuated, but I've made some conscious efforts to manage it better. There were definitely days when I felt overwhelmed, especially when balancing work, my husband's health, and the ongoing pressures of living in Evanston. But I've started to lean more into the coping strategies I've developed over time—like mindfulness, journaling, and setting clear boundaries between work and personal time. I've also found that talking through my feelings with my therapist has been incredibly helpful. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but I've come to see that asking for help is a strength, not a weakness. I've also started incorporating more self-compassion into my daily life, which has made a big difference. Instead of being so hard on myself when things don't go perfectly, I try to remind myself that I'm doing the best I can. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm growing more resilient with each challenge I face.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Abby Schweighardt: Last month, our biggest expenses were definitely housing and healthcare. Rent in Evanston is quite steep, and even though we're in a smaller unit than we'd ideally like, it's still a significant chunk of our budget. We also had some out-of-pocket medical costs related to Daniel's treatment, which added up over time. Groceries and utilities are also pretty high, especially with the way the cost of living has gone up. I try to be careful with our spending, like meal-prepping on the weekends and using public transportation as much as possible to save on gas and car maintenance. We also set aside money each month for savings and retirement, which is something I've always prioritized, partly because of the financial security my parents emphasized growing up. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I feel like we're managing, and I'm grateful for the stability we've built together.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Abby Schweighardt: Our household spent roughly around $5,500 last month, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Normally, we budget around $4,800 to $5,000 a month, depending on how much we spend on groceries and any unexpected expenses. The increase this month was mostly due to Daniel's medical costs, which we hadn't fully anticipated. Housing is our biggest expense—about $2,200 for rent—and then utilities, groceries, and transportation add up to another $1,500 or so. We also set aside around $600 for savings and retirement, which is something I've always prioritized, especially growing up in a family that valued financial responsibility. I try to be mindful of our spending, like meal-prepping and using public transit, but there are still times when things get tight. It's a balancing act, but I feel like we're managing, and I'm grateful for the stability we've built together.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Abby Schweighardt: We rent our home, actually. It's a two-bedroom apartment just a few blocks from the lake, which is one of the reasons we chose this neighborhood. Renting has been the practical choice for us, especially given the uncertainty of the job market and the fact that we're still building our careers. We've considered buying, but with the current housing market and the costs involved, it feels like a big leap we're not quite ready for. Plus, renting gives us more flexibility if we ever decide to move closer to Chicago or explore other opportunities. It's not perfect—rent is a huge chunk of our budget—but it's manageable, and the location makes it all worth it.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Abby Schweighardt: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the cost of living here. In the winter, our utility bills—especially heating—went up quite a bit, which was a challenge since we're already spending so much on rent. We also had higher grocery expenses during the holidays, partly because we like to host friends and family for dinner, and partly because of the general price increases we've seen in food and household items. When school started back up in the fall, we had to factor in more expenses for things like school supplies and extracurricular activities, even though we don't have kids yet. On the other hand, summer brought some relief in terms of lower heating costs, but we had to budget more for travel and outdoor activities, like visiting my in-laws in Wisconsin or going on weekend trips to Chicago. It's been a bit of a rollercoaster, but I've learned to plan a little more ahead and set aside extra money for seasonal changes. It's not always easy, but I feel like we're getting better at managing it, especially with the support of our community and the resources we've found here in Evanston.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and faith have supported me during difficult times, especially with Daniel's illness. It reminded me of how important it is to have a strong support system, both within my family and in the broader community. Talking about how my faith has been a source of comfort and strength helped me reaffirm the role that spirituality plays in my life, especially when facing uncertainty or stress. It also made me think about how I use social media—not as a primary source of support, but as a way to stay connected with people and causes that matter to me. I've come to see that while social media has its place, it's the real, personal connections that make the biggest difference in my emotional well-being. I'm grateful for the people who have been there for me, whether through in-person support, online communities, or just being present in my life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Abby Schweighardt: I definitely save, and it's something I've always prioritized, partly because of the values my parents instilled in me. We have a savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. I also try to set aside money for specific goals, like a down payment on a house or emergency funds. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about huge amounts—it's more about consistency and planning. I also use budgeting apps to track our expenses and make sure we're staying on top of our financial goals. It's not always easy, especially with the rising cost of living here in Evanston, but I believe that saving is a form of self-care and a way to build security for the future. I'm grateful that I've had the discipline to make it a habit, and I hope to pass that mindset on to my future children when the time comes.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Abby Schweighardt: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals, like a down payment on a home. We've been contributing to our emergency fund, which has been especially important given the unexpected medical costs Daniel faced. I also set aside money each month for a future home purchase, even though it feels like a distant dream right now. It's not about being overly cautious—it's about having a sense of security, especially in a place like Evanston where the cost of living can be so unpredictable. I also try to save for small, meaningful things, like a weekend getaway or a special experience with friends. It's not always easy, but I've come to see saving as a way to take control of my future, even in the face of uncertainty.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Abby Schweighardt: I work as a policy analyst for a nonprofit organization focused on education equity, and I also consult with a few local school districts on policy reform initiatives. My job is pretty flexible, which is both a blessing and a challenge. Most days, I'm in the office from around 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I often end up working late, especially when I'm preparing reports or attending meetings with stakeholders. I also have some remote work days, which helps me balance my responsibilities with my personal life. Because I'm not at work right now due to a temporary illness my husband is dealing with, I've had more time to reflect on my career path and how far I've come. It's interesting to think about how my early experiences—like that conversation on my parents' porch—shaped the kind of work I do now. I feel fortunate to be in a field where I can make a tangible difference, even if the days are long and the work is demanding.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Abby Schweighardt: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the month and the projects I'm working on. Some weeks are more structured, with clear start and end times, while others feel like they blur into the weekend, especially when I'm deep into a report or preparing for a big meeting. I try to be intentional about my time, setting boundaries so I can still enjoy the things that matter most—like spending time with Daniel, going for walks by the lake, or catching up with friends. It's not always easy to separate work from life, especially in a field like public policy where the issues we deal with are so deeply tied to people's lives. But I've learned that balance is key, and I'm constantly working on ways to stay productive without burning out. I think that's something I've carried with me since college, when I first realized how much impact this work could have—if I'm not careful, I can get so caught up in the mission that I forget to take care of myself. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be more mindful of my time and energy each day.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Abby Schweighardt: Actually, I did have a second job for a few years early in my career, right after I finished my master's. I was working full-time as a policy analyst for the nonprofit, but I also took on part-time evening work as a research assistant for a local university. It was a lot, but I needed the extra income to help with student loans and to save for our future. The research assistant role was more about data collection and analysis, which actually complemented my policy work. It was challenging juggling both, especially since I was still figuring out my own work-life balance. But looking back, that experience helped me develop a stronger skill set and gave me a deeper understanding of how research informs policy decisions. I don't have a second job now, but I think that period taught me a lot about resilience and the value of hard work—something I carry with me every day.

It also reinforced how much I value the support of my family and the community around me, whether it's through emotional encouragement, financial advice, or just being there when I need it most. I've come to see that both my emotional and financial health are not just personal matters, but deeply connected to the people and systems that surround me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Abby Schweighardt: In total, our household made around $7,200 in the past month. That's from my salary as a policy analyst and Daniel's income as a sustainability consultant. It's not always consistent, especially with the fluctuations in project funding and consulting work, but it's enough to cover our expenses, save a little, and still enjoy the things that make life meaningful—like weekend trips to the lake or a nice dinner out. I know it's not a huge amount, but it feels stable, and I'm grateful for the work we both do. It's also something I think about a lot, especially with the rising cost of living here in Evanston. I try to remind myself that we're not just working for money—we're working to build a life that aligns with our values, and that gives me a sense of purpose even on the tougher days.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Abby Schweighardt: I've been at my current job for about four years now, and it's been a journey of growth and purpose. The benefits package is pretty comprehensive—health insurance covers both of us, which is a huge relief, especially given Daniel's recent health challenges. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which has been really important for maintaining balance. One of the things I appreciate most is the flexibility—they allow remote work days, which helps me manage my schedule better, especially when I need to take care of Daniel or just recharge. There's also a retirement plan and some professional development opportunities, which I've taken advantage of to attend conferences and workshops. While the job can be demanding, the benefits and the sense of making a real difference in education equity make it all worthwhile. I think that's something I've always valued—work that not only pays the bills but also aligns with my values and gives me a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Abby Schweighardt: My relationships at work are pretty collaborative and supportive, which is something I really appreciate. I have a great relationship with my manager—she's been a mentor to me since I started, and she's always encouraged me to take on new challenges and think critically about the policies we're working on. She's also very understanding of the balance between work and personal life, which is something I value a lot, especially given my own experiences. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We're all passionate about education equity, and that shared mission makes it easy to collaborate and support each other. We have regular team meetings, and I think the open communication and mutual respect make our workplace feel like a community rather than just a job. There are definitely days when the work is stressful or the politics get complicated, but overall, I feel like I'm part of a team that genuinely cares about making a difference. That sense of connection is something I carry with me every day, and it reminds me why I chose this path in the first place.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Abby Schweighardt: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is both a blessing and a challenge. On most days, I have a general idea of when I need to be in the office or on a call, but there are also times when I can work from home or adjust my hours to fit around personal responsibilities. For example, if I need to run an errand or take care of something at home, I can usually shift a meeting or task to a different time. That flexibility has been especially helpful during times when Daniel needed more support, like when he was on leave. However, it can also be tricky because the lines between work and personal life can blur, especially when I'm deep in a project or dealing with a tight deadline. I've learned to set boundaries for myself, like designating specific times to check emails or work on reports, but it's something I'm still refining. Overall, I appreciate the flexibility because it allows me to be present for the people and things that matter most, even if it means sometimes working outside of traditional hours.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Abby Schweighardt: Overall, I feel like we're in a stable place financially, even if it's not without its challenges. We're able to cover our basic needs, save a little each month, and still enjoy the things that make life meaningful—like weekend walks by the lake or a nice dinner out. I know we're not rolling in money, but I also know that we're not in a position where we're struggling to make ends meet. That balance feels important to me, especially given my parents' emphasis on financial responsibility growing up. I also appreciate that both of us have careers that align with our values, which gives me a sense of purpose beyond just the numbers. There are definitely days when the cost of living here in Evanston feels overwhelming, but I try to remind myself that we're building a life that matters—not just one that's wealthy. I think that mindset has helped me stay grounded, even when the financial pressures are real.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Abby Schweighardt: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a teacher, and he worked full-time at a local high school in our small town. He always emphasized the importance of education, and I think that's why he chose that career path. My mother worked as a nurse for several years before going back to school for her graduate degree. She worked part-time while she was in school, which was really inspiring to see—she balanced her studies with her job and still managed to be there for my siblings and me. I remember her working late shifts at the hospital and then coming home to help with homework or just have dinner with us. It taught me a lot about dedication and the value of hard work. Even now, I think about how their sacrifices helped shape the kind of person I am today—someone who values education, family, and the importance of contributing to the community in meaningful ways.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Abby Schweighardt: My father was a high school teacher, and his most important activities revolved around teaching and mentoring his students. He had a deep passion for education and often stayed after school to help students who were struggling or needed extra support. He also led extracurricular activities like the debate team and the science club, which I remember being really popular with the kids. He believed that every student had potential, and he worked hard to bring that out in them. My mother, on the other hand, was a nurse, and her most important duties involved caring for patients, especially in the emergency room. She was known for her compassion and dedication, and she often went above and beyond to make sure her patients felt heard and supported. Even when she was working long hours, she always made time for our family. I think both of their jobs taught me the value of service, the importance of showing up for others, and the impact that one person can have in someone else's life. Those lessons have stayed with me, and they're part of why I chose to work in education equity today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Abby Schweighardt: My father worked for the local public school district in our small town, and he was part of a team of educators who were deeply committed to their students' success. He taught high school English, and his classroom was always filled with books, discussions, and a lot of passion. He believed in fostering critical thinking and creativity, and he often encouraged his students to see the world through different perspectives. My mother worked at a community hospital, and she was part of the emergency department team. She was known for her calm demeanor and her ability to connect with patients, even in the most stressful situations. Both of them were employed by organizations that served the public good, and I think that shaped their sense of purpose and the values they passed on to me. They didn't make a lot of money, but they always emphasized that the work they did mattered more than the paycheck. That lesson has stayed with me, and it's something I carry with me in my own career in education equity.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Abby Schweighardt: A few years from now, I hope to still be living in Evanston, maybe in a home we've finally been able to buy, with Daniel and me settled into a rhythm that feels more balanced. I hope we're still working in fields that align with our values—me continuing to make an impact in education equity, and Daniel thriving in his sustainability work. I also hope we're ready to start a family, and that we've created a stable, loving environment for our children to grow up in. I hope I'm still passionate about my work, even if it looks a little different than it does now. I hope I'm still taking time to walk by the lake, to sit on the porch with a cup of coffee, and to be present for the people I love. Most of all, I hope I'm still growing—personally, professionally, and spiritually—and that I'm continuing to learn from the challenges and joys that life brings.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Abby Schweighardt: What I value the most in my life is connection—both with the people I love and with the work I do. I value the relationships I've built with my family, especially Daniel, who has been my rock through every challenge and celebration. I value the sense of community in Evanston, where I feel like I belong and can contribute to something bigger than myself. I also value the work I do in education equity because it aligns with the values my parents instilled in me—service, compassion, and the belief that everyone deserves a fair chance. I value my faith, which gives me strength and a sense of purpose, especially during difficult times. And I value the little things, like the sound of the lake waves, the smell of fresh bread baking, or the quiet moments of reflection on my porch. These things remind me that life is not just about achieving big goals, but about finding meaning in the everyday moments and nurturing the relationships that make it all worthwhile.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial stability and work-life balance are deeply connected to the values I've carried with me since childhood. Talking about our household income and expenses reminded me of how much my parents emphasized financial responsibility, and how I've tried to carry that forward in my own life. It also made me think about the flexibility of my job and how it allows me to be present for the people and things that matter most, like Daniel and our shared values. Describing my workplace and the relationships I have there brought back memories of how my father's dedication to his students and my mother's compassion for her patients shaped the kind of person I am today. I've come to see that my work isn't just about making a living—it's about making a difference, and that sense of purpose is something I carry with me every day.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It reminded me of how deeply my past, present, and future are intertwined with the people, values, and choices that have shaped me. From my childhood in a small town, where my parents instilled in me the importance of education and hard work, to the crossroads I faced after college that led me to public policy, every step has been guided by the support of family, mentors, and a strong sense of purpose. Living in Evanston, with its community spirit and connection to the lake, has become a place where I feel grounded and inspired. My relationship with Daniel, my husband, has been a source of strength and shared values, and together we continue to build a life that aligns with our dreams. The challenges we've faced, like Daniel's illness, have tested our resilience, but they've also deepened our bond and reminded me of the importance of mental and emotional well-being. Through it all, I've come to see that life is not just about the big decisions or the financial stability, but about the connections we nurture, the values we uphold, and the small, meaningful moments that make life worth living. This reflection has helped me appreciate the journey I've been on and the path I still have ahead.
